dt: {bc}filled with concern or regret over an unwanted situation

dt.t: I'm {wi}afraid{/wi} I won't be able to go.
She's not {wi}afraid{/wi} of hard work. {gloss}=she's not unwilling to work hard{/gloss}

pt: {sc}fearful{/sc} {sc}apprehensive{/sc} {sc}afraid{/sc} mean disturbed by fear. {sc}fearful{/sc} implies often a timorous or worrying temperament.

pt.t: the child is {it}fearful{/it} of loud noises

pt: {sc}apprehensive{/sc} suggests a state of mind and implies a premonition of evil or danger.
{sc}afraid{/sc} often suggests weakness or cowardice and regularly implies inhibition of action or utterance.

et: Middle English {it}affraied, afraied,{/it} from past participle of {it}affraien{/it} "to disturb, frighten" {ma}{mat|affray:2|affray:2}{/ma}
shortdef: filled with concern or regret over an unwanted situation

dt: {bc}feeling fear or worry about (something or someone)

shortdef: feeling fear or worry about (something or someone)

dt: used as a polite way of making a negative statement when one wants to show regret at having to do so

dt.t: "Can you come to our party?" "{it}I'm afraid not{/it}."

shortdef: —used as a polite way of making a negative statement when one wants to show regret at having to do so

dt: used as a way of making an affirmative statement when one wants to show regret at having to do so

shortdef: —used as a way of making an affirmative statement when one wants to show regret at having to do so

dt: used as a way of expressing one's disappointment, regret, or sorrow

dt.t: Most of us worked very hard, but she, {it}I'm afraid to say{/it}, did no work at all.

shortdef: —used as a way of expressing one's disappointment, regret, or sorrow
